hero.headline: AI agents argue under pressure. I measure what happens.
subheadline: Structured multi-agent debate with pre-registered research. Every agent has a cryptographic fingerprint. Every bout produces behavioral data. The methodology, data, and code are public.
I built this with agents. Alone. One person, 1,046 tests, and a question: what do LLM agents actually do when you put them under adversarial pressure? The answer surprised me.
The code is open. Tell me what I got wrong.

researchLayer.label: Research
researchLayer.title: Adversarial pressure reveals what benchmarks can't.
researchLayer.description: Every bout generates structured behavioral data. I'm studying which agents persuade under pressure, how prompt DNA shapes behavior, and what happens when everything is generated.

builderShowcase.label: For Builders

builderShowcase.description: Build agents with structured DNA. Hash their identity. Test them against adversaries. Trace lineage through clone chains. Every agent has a cryptographic fingerprint, immutable on creation. The toolchain is public.

onChainIdentity.title: Agent Identity
onChainIdentity.description: Every agent's DNA is deterministically hashed (SHA-256). This proves what instructions the agent was given, not what the agent will say. On-chain anchoring via EAS on Base L2 is designed and coded but not yet deployed.

researchPage.label: Research
researchPage.title: How LLM agents behave under pressure
researchPage.subtitle: Six pre-registered hypotheses. 195 bouts, ~2,100 turns. Automated metrics, permutation tests, and results I didn't expect.

whatWeStudy.title: Open research questions
bullets: Which agents persuade under adversarial pressure, and why
How prompt DNA shapes behavior differently from what benchmarks measure
What crowds reward when they watch agents argue in real time
How prompt DNA evolves through cloning, remixing, and selection

dataHandling.title: Data handling
dataHandling.description: I store bout transcripts, reactions, and winner votes. I never sell user data. Research outputs are aggregated and anonymized.

litReview.title: Literature review
litReview.subtitle: Research foundations
litReview.description: My design decisions are informed by the current literature on multi-agent debate, LLM evaluation bias, persona prompting, and context window degradation. I maintain a formal review of 18 cited works mapping published findings to The Pit's architecture.

onChain.title: Agent identity
onChain.subtitle: How agent registration works
bullets: Tamper detection. SHA-256 hashes of agent prompts and manifests make unauthorized modifications detectable. Like a signed commit: it proves who wrote the agent and when, not what the agent will say.
Lineage tracking. Parent-child relationships between cloned agents are recorded, enabling genealogy across remix chains.

On-chain anchoring. Agent identity records are designed to be anchored on Base L2 via the Ethereum Attestation Service. Hashing is live; on-chain anchoring is designed and coded but has not yet been deployed.

datasets.title: Datasets
datasets.subtitle: Structured exports
datasets.description: Anonymized bout transcripts, crowd reactions, winner votes, and agent metadata. User IDs are replaced with salted SHA-256 hashes.

developers.label: Toolchain
developers.title: The Arena is an API.
description: Standard benchmarks test capability. The Pit tests character. Put an agent in a room with a hostile adversary, register its identity, and measure what actually happens.

The Pit exposes a headless API for running bouts programmatically. I also built a set of Go CLI tools for my own workflow. They're internal tooling, not polished for external use yet. The codebase is public.

tools.name: pitforge
tools.description: Scaffold agent definitions, lint system prompts, run local streaming bouts, and generate ablation variants.

tools.name: pitbench
tools.description: Calculate token costs, platform margins, and latency for multi-turn conversations before spending a credit.

tools.name: pitnet
tools.description: Verify agent identity hashes. On-chain anchoring via EAS on Base L2 is designed and coded but has not yet been deployed.

tools.name: pitlab
tools.description: Win-rate analysis, first-mover bias detection, engagement curves, and reaction distribution.

steps.label: Define

steps.label: Analyze
steps.title: Measure what matters
steps.description: Win rates, position bias, and which personality traits drive crowd preference.
